fields.description:
As a cloud user, I would like to store my LB's access logs to OSG buckets so that I can troubleshoot my application's problems and monitor access logs.

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ElasticLoadBalancing/latest/DeveloperGuide/access-log-collection.html
fields.summary: ELB: Access logs in OSG bucket
Use system accounts to manage ELB resources

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

comments.body:
You can follow these steps (in AWS cli) to test:

1) As a non-eucalyptus account, create an ELB.
aws elb --region us-east-1 --endpoint-url http://10.111.1.73:8773/services/LoadBalancing create-load-balancer --load-balancer-name accesslog-test-elb --listeners "Protocol=HTTP,LoadBalancerPort=80,InstanceProtocol=HTTP,InstancePort=8000"  --availability-zones one

aws elb --region us-east-1 --endpoint-url http://10.111.1.73:8773/services/LoadBalancing  describe-load-balancers
aws elb --region us-east-1 --endpoint-url http://10.111.1.73:8773/services/LoadBalancing  register-instances-with-load-balancer --load-balancer-name accesslog-test-elb --instances i-96b4c689 i-1f249818
aws elb --region us-east-1 --endpoint-url http://10.111.1.73:8773/services/LoadBalancing  describe-instance-health --load-balancer-name accesslog-test-elb

2) Try describing load-balancer attributes and make sure AccessLog attribute is set to false.
 aws elb --region us-east-1 --endpoint-url http://10.111.1.73:8773/services/LoadBalancing  describe-load-balancer-attributes --load-balancer-name accesslog-test-elb

3) Create a bucket where the logs will be written.
s3cmd -c ./s3cfg mb s3://myaccesslog

4) The users will need to allow ELB's system account(a new feature which replaces eucalyptus account). To do it, use 'euare-accountlist' to find out the account ID of the system account. For example:
(eucalyptus)loadbalancing	000250898784

Now set write ACL with the account ID.
s3cmd -c ./s3cfg --acl-grant=write:000250898784 setacl s3://myaccesslog

5) Modify lb attribute to enable AccessLog.
aws elb --region us-east-1 --endpoint-url http://10.111.1.73:8773/services/LoadBalancing modify-load-balancer-attributes --load-balancer-name accesslog-test-elb --load-balancer-attributes "{\"AccessLog\":{\"Enabled\":true,\"S3BucketName\":\"myaccesslog\",\"EmitInterval\":5,\"S3BucketPrefix\":\"myapp\"}}"

Here the emit interval is set 5 min which means you will be able to see the logs in the next 5 minute.

6) Do 'curl' on the ELB to generate some requests. 

7) Find out that the log is written in the bucket. The directory structure follows AWS convention: http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ElasticLoadBalancing/latest/DeveloperGuide/access-log-collection.html

 s3cmd -c ./s3cfg ls 
s3://myaccesslog/myapp/AWSLogs/000104238750/elasticloadbalancing/eucalyptus/2015/4/28/
~                       

8) Download the log file and make sure the file contains log lines per AWS docs.
[~spark], regular users currently cannot see system accounts (using euare-accountlist). What's the expected way for them to find account number for (eucalyptus)loadbalancing?

[~rusvika] We do not have a discovery mechanism for it, but should document that it should be obtained from their cloud admins. That's unfortunate consequence of having no static ID for the services (http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ElasticLoadBalancing/latest/DeveloperGuide/enable-access-logs.html#attach-bucket-policy)

[~spark],

Since we don't have a discovery mechanism for it, could this be something added into the GUI?  Also, could we come up with some documentation for cloud administrators on leveraging cross-account roles to allow accounts to display ELB account ID for each region? From a usability point of view, this would pretty bad from the perspective of the cloud administrator.

Enabled access logging, started churn using curl against the ELB.  No logs ever showed up.  Only file in the bucket was file uploaded via s3cmd by the '(eucalyptus)loadbalancing/admin' user to confirm bucket ACLs were correct.  Saw following error in servo logs:
{code}
2015-09-23 15:05:02,263 servo [DEBUG]:access log bucket name: nginx-access-logs
2015-09-23 15:05:02,263 servo [DEBUG]:access log bucket prefix: nginx
2015-09-23 15:05:02,264 servo [DEBUG]:access log emit interval: 5
2015-09-23 15:05:02,264 servo [DEBUG]:access log enabled?: True
2015-09-23 15:05:02,264 servo [DEBUG]:to-add: 0, to-delete: 0
2015-09-23 15:05:02,264 servo [DEBUG]:listener updated
2015-09-23 15:05:02,265 servo [DEBUG]:reported the metrics: 0-0-0-0-0-0-0-0
2015-09-23 15:05:04,775 servo [ERROR]:Failed to emit access logs: S3ResponseError: 403 Forbidden

2015-09-23 15:05:12,316 servo [DEBUG]:access log bucket name: nginx-access-logs
2015-09-23 15:05:12,316 servo [DEBUG]:access log bucket prefix: nginx
2015-09-23 15:05:12,317 servo [DEBUG]:access log emit interval: 5
2015-09-23 15:05:12,317 servo [DEBUG]:access log enabled?: True
2015-09-23 15:05:12,317 servo [DEBUG]:to-add: 0, to-delete: 0
2015-09-23 15:05:12,317 servo [DEBUG]:listener updated
{code}

*Steps*

# Set up Eucalyptus 4.2 (4.2.0-0.0.23890.654.20150918git84e694a.el6) with Eucalyptus DNS enabled - [hspencer-1321|http://jenkins.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/job/Quick%20Launch%20Master/1321/]
# Created 'devops' account, and added access and secret keys to 'devops/admin' user
# Created ELB, then autoscaling group.  Linked autoscaling group to ELB:
{code}
[root@c-02 ~]# eulb-describe-lbs --region devops-admin@region-1 --show-long
LOAD_BALANCER	NginxLoadBalancers	NginxLoadBalancers-000693176866.lb.c-02.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com			{interval=60,target=HTTP:80/,timeout=2,healthy-threshold=3,unhealthy-threshold=3}	one,two			i-c6422ef7,i-5d6398f7	{protocol=HTTP,lb-port=80,instance-protocol=HTTP,instance-port=80}					{owner-alias=000770154596,group-name=euca-internal-000693176866-NginxLoadBalancers}		2015-09-21T20:59:23.206Z	internet-facing
[root@c-02 ~]# euscale-describe-auto-scaling-groups --show-long --region devops-admin@region-1
AUTO-SCALING-GROUP	NginxScalingGroup	NginxConfigV2	one,two	2015-09-21T15:33:59.731Z	NginxLoadBalancers	EC2	2	4	2	300	0			arn:aws:autoscaling::000693176866:autoScalingGroup:ba624b96-3ea9-46ee-b2cc-ea82b985b5dc:autoScalingGroupName/NginxScalingGroup	Default
INSTANCE	i-c6422ef7	one	InService	Healthy	NginxConfigV2
INSTANCE	i-5d6398f7	two	InService	Healthy	NginxConfigV2
{code}
# Confirmed curl worked against ELB:
{code}
[root@c-02 ~]# curl -I NginxLoadBalancers-000693176866.lb.c-02.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.9.3 (Ubuntu)
Date: Wed, 23 Sep 2015 16:53:09 GMT
Content-Type: text/html
Content-Length: 612
Last-Modified: Tue, 22 Sep 2015 14:11:27 GMT
ETag: "5601618f-264"
Accept-Ranges: bytes
{code}
# Downloaded s3cmd from Github; set up configuration file using 'devops/admin' user credentials
# Created bucket for access logs, then added bucket ACLs for '(eucalyptus)loadbalancing' account:
{code}
[root@c-02 ~]# ./s3cmd/s3cmd --signature-v2 mb s3://nginx-access-logs
Bucket 's3://nginx-access-logs/' created
[root@c-02 ~]# euare-accountlist --region cloud-admin@region-1
(eucalyptus)imaging	000647791497
(eucalyptus)aws-exec-read	000987058328
eucalyptus	000466351755
(eucalyptus)database	000892121492
(eucalyptus)objectstorage	000007610758
(eucalyptus)cloudformation	000925368683
devops	000693176866
spark	000389728261
(eucalyptus)loadbalancing	000770154596
(eucalyptus)blockstorage	000418676798
engineering	000016805899
[root@c-02 ~]# ./s3cmd/s3cmd --signature-v2 --acl-grant=write_acp:000770154596 setacl s3://nginx-access-logs
s3://nginx-access-logs/: ACL updated
{code}
# Confirmed '(eucalyptus)loadbalancing/admin' user could write to bucket:
{code}
[root@c-02 ~]# ./s3cmd/s3cmd --signature-v2 -c .s3cfg-elb put install.log s3://nginx-access-logs/install.log
'install.log' -> 's3://nginx-access-logs/install.log'  [1 of 1]
 16875 of 16875   100% in    0s   117.34 kB/s  done
{code}
# Used 'eulb-modify-lb-attributes' to enable 5 minute log rotation for access logs on ELB:
{code}
[root@c-02 ~]# eulb-modify-lb-attributes NginxLoadBalancers AccessLog.Enabled=True AccessLog.S3BucketName=nginx-access-logs AccessLog.EmitInterval=5 AccessLog.S3BucketPrefix=nginx --region devops-admin@region-1
[root@c-02 ~]# eulb-describe-lb-attributes NginxLoadBalancers --region devops-admin@region-1
AccessLog.EmitInterval	5
AccessLog.Enabled	true
AccessLog.S3BucketName	nginx-access-logs
AccessLog.S3BucketPrefix	nginx
ConnectionDraining.Enabled	false
ConnectionSettings.IdleTimeout	60
CrossZoneLoadBalancing.Enabled	false
{code}
# Ran curl against ELB for about 10 minutes generate logs into bucket:
{code}
# while true; do curl -I NginxLoadBalancers-000693176866.lb.c-02.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com; done
{code}
# Listed bucket contents to confirm log delivery:
{code}
[root@c-02 ~]# ./s3cmd/s3cmd --signature-v2 ls s3://nginx-access-logs
2015-09-23 13:00     16875   s3://nginx-access-logs/install.log
{code}
# SSH'd into one of the load balancers to confirm load-balancer-servo received update; noticed {{S3ResponseError: 403 Forbidden}} error:
{code}
2015-09-23 15:04:11,980 servo [DEBUG]:access log bucket name: nginx-access-logs

EUCA-11064 relates to discovery for loadbalancing account information.

*Update*

I downloaded s3cmd onto one of the ELB instances, and used the instance profile credentials provided by the instance meta-data:
{code}
[cloud-user@euca-10-111-76-20 ~]$ curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/iam/security-credentials/loadbalancer-vm-000693176866-NginxLoadBalancers; echo
{
  "Code": "Success",
  "LastUpdated": "2015-09-23T17:51:36Z",
  "Type": "AWS-HMAC",
  "AccessKeyId": "AKIAA7ESNLF4WRITPP2G",

  "Expiration": "2015-09-23T18:51:36Z"
}
[cloud-user@euca-10-111-76-20 ~]$ cat /etc/load-balancer-servo/boto.cfg
[Boto]
metadata_service_timeout = 30.0
{code}
{code}
[cloud-user@euca-10-111-76-20 ~]$ ./s3cmd/s3cmd --configure

Refer to user manual for detailed description of all options.

Default Region [US]:

by unauthorized persons while in transfer to S3
Encryption password:

[default]
When using secure HTTPS protocol all communication with Amazon S3
servers is protected from 3rd party eavesdropping. This method is
slower than plain HTTP, and can only be proxied with Python 2.7 or newer
Use HTTPS protocol [Yes]: NO

On some networks all internet access must go through a HTTP proxy.
Try setting it here if you can't connect to S3 directly
HTTP Proxy server name:

New settings:
  Access Key: AKIAALLVAVUHARNLNYRK
  Secret Key: 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
  Default Region: US
  Encryption password:
  Path to GPG program: /usr/bin/gpg
  Use HTTPS protocol: False
  HTTP Proxy server name:
  HTTP Proxy server port: 0

Test access with supplied credentials? [Y/n] n

Save settings? [y/N] y
Configuration saved to '/home/cloud-user/.s3cfg'

[cloud-user@euca-10-111-76-20 ~]$ grep objectstorage .s3cfg
host_base = objectstorage.c-02.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773
host_bucket = %(bucket)s.objectstorage.c-02.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773
{code}

I tried to upload a file to the bucket, but I got {{S3 error: 403 (AccessDenied): Access Denied}}:
{code}
[cloud-user@euca-10-111-76-20 ~]$ ./s3cmd/s3cmd --signature-v2 put cloud-init.log s3://nginx-access-logs/cloud-init.log
'cloud-init.log' -> 's3://nginx-access-logs/cloud-init.log'  [1 of 1]
 63832 of 63832   100% in    0s   698.45 kB/s  done
ERROR: S3 error: 403 (AccessDenied): Access Denied
{code}

Is there something additional that needs to be done when adding permission to the bucket for the '(eucalyptus)loadbalancing' account to have access?
[~hspencer], are you using the security token with S3? the key/secret are not valid without the token.

[~sjones], Ya, it populates in the .s3cfg file when you run {{s3cmd --configure}}. {code} [cloud-user@euca-10-111-76-20 ~]$ grep access .s3cfg access_key = AKIAALLVAVUHARNLNYRK access_token = ZXVjYQABLWR8UUALATrjk5cmsaqrU5oS8Z6GyFOU7iG8x68PFx4DiVLtHcUVusr3GV+KgtVE3J3nCYAwzAsG2MVT0Y+P3jTQUlenOnAT5OdHJ1OHc0enui1TtM2DBlbqRvrlJST0TzRo3zbqRv64dW+YEl8qm7KToagk84J8e7MocEf//jrErika+txzTmGzLr7YmawiGakLFeZ2oDVKC4y01hyrp59wDgYeUgsrUcNjcR/t/mpwMPPl2LhB3A== [~hspencer] Your steps look good. Is the system still up? Can I take a look?

[~hspencer] The issue was due to incorrect description of the permission given to the ELB system account. The granted permission should be 'full_control' (or write, read, write_acp), not 'write_acp'.  
(i.e.,  ./s3cmd/s3cmd --signature-v2 --acl-grant=full_control:000770154596 setacl s3://nginx-access-logs )

I will update my comment above.
CC-ing [~dkavanagh][~kgill]: previously not sufficient permission was granted to ELB system account. This may have an impact to console's access log.
[~spark], why is "write" permission not sufficient? ELB should not need to read data from the bucket or change the ACL.

[~sjones] "read" was due to the way boto write objects to bucket. We may get around it. Then, 'write_acp' was added to allow ELB's to grant "full_control" permission of logs to ELB owners. Not sure if there is other way to give the permission to the owner.. And if 'write_acp' is necessary, then I think it's equivalent to the full control because ELB can re-write the ACL.
We have been able to enable elb logging via the console with a bucket we create. I haven't tried other buckets with varied ACLs.
[~dkavanagh] EUCA-11346 could have hidden the bug. Did you try it in the recent build?

[~spark],

Just to confirm - are these the only ACLs that need to be added to the bucket for the {{(eucalyptus)loadbalancing}} account:
- write
- write_acp

I didn't think the 'read' ACL was needed here, but just wanted to make sure.

[~spark]/[~rusvika]:

Regarding the account ID for {{(eucalyptus)loadbalancing}} - I think a workaround for now is to use the owner-alias that is displayed for the load balancer when it is described.  For example:
{code}
[root@c-02 ~]# eulb-describe-lbs ELB-Zone1 --show-long --region devops-admin@region-1
LOAD_BALANCER	ELB-Zone1	ELB-Zone1-000693176866.lb.c-02.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com			{interval=30,target=TCP:80,timeout=5,healthy-threshold=3,unhealthy-threshold=3}	one				{protocol=HTTP,lb-port=80,instance-protocol=HTTP,instance-port=80}					{owner-alias=000770154596,group-name=euca-internal-000693176866-ELB-Zone1}		2015-09-24T14:07:56.963Z	internet-facing
{code}
Until we are able to get similar set up like AWS, I think this will have to do.  Thoughts?

[~hspencer] That is the proper log files that we should see. I think 'read' is necessary, so probably makes sense to just say 'full_control', given the combination of permissions required. Regarding the account ID (or canonical ID), DescribeServices now expose that information to regular accounts. For example, you can try 'euca-describe-services' to see the IDs for the services.

[~hspencer] That's right. 'read' was necessary due to boto's way of writing an object. But we also require 'write_acp' which is to allow writing ACL and that means we're giving ELB the permission to do anything on the bucket.

[~hspencer], there is a separation between the euca2ool and the API call. DescribeServices is alive and well on the empyrean endpoint and the euca2ools have been re-factored to better reflect the service they talk to.

[~spark],

I am not sure if you tried this, but looking at the [code in load_balancer_servo repo under access_logger.py|https://github.com/eucalyptus/load-balancer-servo/blob/master/servo/mon/access_logger.py#L110], I see the following:
{code}
bucket = conn.get_bucket(self.bucket_name)
{code}
Its true that by default, if you use [{{get_bucket}}|http://boto.readthedocs.org/en/latest/ref/s3.html#boto.s3.connection.S3Connection.get_bucket], the app/user needs 'read' ACL on the bucket.  This is so that boto can do a LIST operation on the bucket.  To not have that happen (since the ELB doesn't need to list the contents of the bucket), one can pass the option {{validate=False}}.  This way 'read' is not needed \[[1|http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11478752/with-the-boto-library-can-i-avoid-granting-list-permissions-on-a-base-bucket-in]\]. Did this not work in this case?

- \[1\] http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11478752/with-the-boto-library-can-i-avoid-granting-list-permissions-on-a-base-bucket-in
[~hspencer] Thanks! I think that should work. You can do PR or I can fix my self too. Still I think we should say 'full_control' unless we have a way to avoid 'write_acp'.
[~spark], I assume you could specify the permissions when putting the object to avoid needing 'write_acp'.

[~sjones] That was right. I could use the canned acl 'bucket-owner-full-control' when I put the object. Thanks for the info!
I'll commit the fix that will require only 'write' permission.
[~hspencer] If you want to test it, you can pull the latest from https://github.com/eucalyptus/load-balancer-servo/ and do 'python setup.py install'. Then you can reboot the servo Vm.

[~spark], good work here.  Thanks for the feedback [~sjones].

Fixed.

Eucalyptus Version: {{4.2.0-0.0.23913.667.20150924git57c7fca.el6}}

*Steps*

# Set up multi-cluster, single region Eucalyptus 4.2 (4.2.0-0.0.23913.667.20150924git57c7fca.el6) cloud with Eucalyptus DNS enabled - [hspencer-1403|http://jenkins.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/job/Quick%20Launch%20Master/1403/]
# Created 'devops' account and added credentials for 'devops/admin' user.
# Create ELB with 'devops/admin' user:
{code}
[root@a-18 ~]# eulb-create-lb -z cash,money -l "lb-port=80, protocol=HTTP, instance-port=80, instance-protocol=HTTP" NginxWebServers --region devops-admin@region-1
DNS_NAME	NginxWebServers-000476918024.lb.a-18.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com

[root@a-18 ~]# eulb-describe-lbs --show-long --region devops-admin@region-1
LOAD_BALANCER	NginxWebServers	NginxWebServers-000476918024.lb.a-18.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com			{interval=30,target=TCP:80,timeout=5,healthy-threshold=3,unhealthy-threshold=3	cash,money				{protocol=HTTP,lb-port=80,instance-protocol=HTTP,instance-port=80}					{owner-alias=000865102303,group-name=euca-internal-000476918024-NginxWebServers}		2015-09-29T18:11:33.761Z	internet-facing
{code}
# Create autoscaling config, then create autoscaling group:
{code}
[root@a-18 ~]# euscale-describe-launch-configs --region devops-admin@region-1 --show-long
LAUNCH-CONFIG	NginxConfig	emi-025c097e	m1.large					nginx-sg	2015-09-29T16:25:10.181Z	true	arn:aws:autoscaling::000476918024:launchConfiguration:455fe808-893f-47df-a0eb-252bb9afb7d5:launchConfigurationName/NginxConfig

[root@a-18 ~]# euscale-create-auto-scaling-group -l NginxConfig --desired-capacity 2 -m 2 -M 2 --health-check-type EC2 --load-balancers NginxWebServers --tag "k=application, v=nginx" --availability-zones cash,money NginxWebGroup --region devops-admin@region-1

[root@a-18 ~]# eulb-describe-lbs --show-long --region devops-admin@region-1
LOAD_BALANCER	NginxWebServers	NginxWebServers-000476918024.lb.a-18.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com			{interval=30,target=TCP:80,timeout=5,healthy-threshold=3,unhealthy-threshold=3	cash,money			i-6f2a1874,i-be660343	{protocol=HTTP,lb-port=80,instance-protocol=HTTP,instance-port=80}					{owner-alias=000865102303,group-name=euca-internal-000476918024-NginxWebServers}		2015-09-29T18:11:33.761Z	internet-facing
